p: Influenza B virus of the Orthomyxoviridae family [1] has a segmented single stranded, negative sense RNA genome. First isolated in 1940, influenza B virus diverged into two lineages, Victoria and Yamagata, in the late 1970s with similar clinical [2] but different phylodynamic properties [3]. Although infections in pigs and seals were observed, there is no known animal reservoir for influenza B [4]. Thus, while influenza A infections can be zoonotic, influenza B virus only circulates in the human population. The narrow host range and slower evolution [5] are thought to be the main contributing factors to the less frequent occurrence of influenza B epidemics [6].
